awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for the Twentieth Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS 2024) and the 33rd USENIX Security Symposium (USENIX Security 2024)
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Security Conference is one of the most important research conferences for professionals to present cutting edge research of fundamental importance to advancing understanding of computer systems security.  Its co-located conference, the Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS) is a leading venue for research on security and privacy topics as they relate to people, organizations, and society.  This award will support student travel to the 33rd edition of USENIX Security and the 20th edition of SOUPS, to be held Aug 11-16, 2024 in Philadelphia.  Funding this travel will allow student researchers to connect to experts from across the academic, government, and industry communities to foster cross-disciplinary approaches and to address shared research challenges. 

This award will provide travel support to about 28 students who who otherwise have limited travel funding and so might not be able to attend.  The funding will allow students to present at the conference and receive valuable mentoring both at the conference and beyond, through an online community that supports attendees.  Criteria for selection include financial need, conference participation, close alignment with conference topics, first-time attendance, and diversity of personal and institutional backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based graduate students to attend two USENIX events in 2024, specifically the Twentieth Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS 2024) and the 33rd USENIX Security Symposium (USENIX Security ‘24).

SOUPS 2024 took place August 11-13, 2024, in Philadelphia, PA, and focused on human-computer interaction, security, and privacy. USENIX Security ‘24, which took place August 14-16, 2024, in the same location, was a forum for the latest advances in the security and privacy of computer systems and networks.

Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work in the field. This grant made possible the participation of students, primarily Ph.D. candidates, who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. Students who participated in each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including speed mentoring events, a student meetup, poster sessions, and receptions. The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for SOUPS 2024 and USENIX Security ‘24. 

Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. For those students selected, USENIX covered registration costs by providing students with a registration code for full student registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist the student with costs related to airfare and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the amount they requested (i.e., some students may stay with a friend in the town of the conference and therefore not have a hotel expense). We confirmed that the student recipients registered and attended the event. 

The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

  • Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster)

  • Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics

  • The pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicant’s research

  • Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months

  • Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events

  • Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities

  • Class level, prioritizing graduate students, and financial need

The NSF funds supported 38 grants for students to participate in the two events. 

  • For SOUPS 2024, USENIX received 33 grant applications from students and awarded 18 grants. The NSF funds of $12,500 covered 14 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 270 attendees at SOUPS 2024, which included 95 student attendees.

  • For USENIX Security ‘24, we received 160 grant applications from students and awarded 70 grants. The NSF funds of $27,500 covered 24 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 1,020 attendees at Security ‘24, which included 348 people registered as student attendees.
